But how do we really know unless we try, fear will keep us in bondage, and as Edward said it will become worse each passing day, so what do have to loose? Â @KenchiManokÂ  Dear Bleeding Heart, you are misguided, no doubt influenced by Stone's film. The federal intelligence agencies like the CIA & NSA usually hire only pragmatic people, as opposed to idealists who believe and act opposite that of their government.   I would agree with the idea the feds should not be able to spy on whomever the want to without a court order but it happens and when it does, it is usually for national security purposes.   Besides, the feds do not have the time, money or manpower to spy on everybody, just people of interest. And they better have a good reason because the feds are accountable.   There are the military industrial complex companies, the military contractors whose workforce is based mostly in California and various southern states.   Then there is the federal intelligence work force, composed mostly of people who have lived for generation in Maryland, Delaware, Washington DC, Virginia and the Carolina's.   These families, generation after generation, become federal employees and deeply rooted in their communities and in their careers at the CIA, NSA, FBI, Homeland Security, Secret Service and at least a dozen other intelligence agencies. You will never get rid of them and no single man will ever b e able to change the way they do business. Snowden is considered an enemy by these people. Most of them.   Let's face it, federal intelligence agencies sometimes have to act outside the law, by virtue of the fact they are engaged in clandestine spy craft, espionage and saboteur work, as well as assassinations, which no court would ever sign off on but is sometimes required for political or security reasons.   I am not defending the feds, merely understanding where they are coming from. Snowden should have realized he was throwing his life away by committing treason. This is what he did.   The Russians, Chinese, North Koreans, the Iranians, etc. have all gained valuable information from the material Snowden made public through The Guardian.   Now he lives in a communist state, Russia, long known for the oppressive way the government has treated it's own citizens, which seems like just desserts for Snowden. He has become, in some ways, Number Six,  The Prisoner.

Snowden is a confusing case.... He now has asylum in Russia. Can I blame him? No, I can't. Maybe I'd go to Russia also in his case. Do I think there couldn't be more to this story? Before everyone praises Snowden, please watch John McAfees interview on Snowden because I consider McAfee as having nothing to lose, and very honest in that interview. It's very important to get a counter point before blindly believing one man at face value. Hear them both, and then decide what you personally think.   Also, thank you Snowden. I believe almost all of what you've said intuitively, I'm only unsure about the intentions. A traitor is someone who commits actions against his own government, for the sake of supporting a known enemy of that government.  See the distinction? Snowden may have committed an action against his government, and sought refuge in another country. But what we need to debate here was his intent with releasing those documents. Was he attempting to support Al-Qaida? Then he's a traitor. Was he trying to enlighten his fellow citizens and support the people he was sworn to protect? Then although his actions can be arguably legal/illegal, good/bad, he certainly isn't a traitor- he was trying to help his country rather than betray it.  I think we should be a lot more careful with that word- it delineates a specific kind of intent along with an action, but people tend to just attribute it to the action without the prerequisite intent present.   And the courts make it illegal for the accused to mention what their motives are/were when accused under espionnage. Ridiculous.

There's a fundamental irony about Edward Snowdon which unfortunately doesn't get addressed in this otherwise excellent podcast.  The basic urge that drove him to expose the NSA (and still clearly drives him now) is a need to make the American people aware of a creeping totalitarianism in the US government that they were/are unaware of, and which is against the fundamental tenets of their democracy. He's saying "Look people, this is happening, and here's the proof. We need to fight this or all is lost: our democratic rights and freedoms are gone forever."   That's wonderful, but look where he's ended up: in the lap of one of the nastiest, most totalitarian regimes in the world, who long since trampled over whatever few rights the Russians had, and use state power in the most brutal way against their own people on a routine daily basis.   It's a pity Joe didn't point that out and query it. (Mind you he could hardly get a word in edgeways because this was basically a monologue, not a discussion).   Furthermore this sinister, cynical, gangster state is only giving Snowdon sanctuary because it serves its purpose well to have a passionate, powerful critic of its secret service adversaries in the West keeping up his eviscerating attack on what they do, and how they do it. What a gift!  And where does Ed choose to make this particular attack? The Joe Rogan show, hosted on YouTube, which is owned by none other than Google - one of the tech giants Edward Snowdon loves to hate, because of their all pervading surveillance of our lives...   Irony piled on irony... It would be funny if it weren't so tragic!  These fundamental paradoxes are something Snowdon should reflect as deeply upon as he does on everything else - but strangely they seem to have eluded his gaze. Sadly Joe doesn't seem to grasp them either. Disappointing from both of them.

there's ways. I was raised on internet privacy and security, it's part of my dad's job. there's still ways to be completely anonymous and secure, but you can't go around common websites and ever expect to accomplish that. I have a separate computer on a different network for anything important. I don't browse the web on that computer, I use different network utilities to contact people.  it's not easy, you really have to know what you're doing, but it is possible. these days I'm a "hacker" or tinkerer as I prefer. it's not something I particularly enjoy anymore, but staying private and safe is what I know.  for example, I never buy modern computers, especially anything shipped from outside the US, and I'm careful where I buy my refurbished computers. the NSA puts chips in all modern computers, it used to be the motherboard but now it's always integrated into the CPU courtesy of Intel and likely AMD as well at this point. you can't trust the government because they don't trust you.
Â @alllovelainÂ  how would a chip on a CPU even work, it would basically have to be its own second computer on the CPU
Â @EpochIsEpicÂ  no, think of it like another, separate, function of the CPU. it's basically impossible to get rid of but there are some ways around it.
Â @alllovelainÂ  what exactly does it do?
Â @EpochIsEpicÂ  it does a lot these days. look into Intel ME and AMD PSP.
Â @alllovelainÂ  Interesting. Thanks for the rabbit hole!

Â @EpochIsEpicÂ  no problem, it's one of the bigger rabbit holes in tech and it's something I feel everyone with a computer should be aware of. the closest to the hardware I've ever worked with is ring 1, one step of permissions above the kernel. to think they'd develop something so strange that's -3 is disturbing to me. they're never specific about exactly what all it does or is capable of, but those in the Linux community have been very concerned for years and have outed a lot of what it can do, just knowing that it can transfer information without wifi and without being turned on is disturbing. it's purely for spying, it seems. as the Wikipedia page mentions, developers in the libreboot (a bootloader, what appears before your OS launches and let's you select an OS to boot into) project know about some things it can do. I've been using Linux since I was a kid and it makes me sad to see how they couldn't spy on Linux users through software, so they went far below firmware level to do it and now Linux has been bought by these corporations that work for the government.

The Founding Fathers generally knew that government was, at best, a necessary evil.  This is a perfect illustration of why they felt that way.  Governments are comprised of imperfect humans, hence the checks and balances system they devised for us.  Human nature is governed by temptation, fear of shame, and a thirst for power.   After our countryâ€™s founding it became wildly successful, probably beyond anything the Founding Fathers imagined.  With that our federal (central) government has also exploded. It has become so large that more and more abuses can by hidden and have no real checks against them.  National security agencies, because of their mission, should have triple the checks on them that you would normally have on a government agency. Their stated mission is important (defend us from enemies foreign and domestic) but in the worldâ€™s premier democracy it is essential that private citizensâ€™ rights and privacy are protected as much as possible to a standard that is difficult, inconvenient and paramount within their mission.

The US wanted Snowden to do what he did, they wanted him to become a whistle-blower and leak information. Why? It makes sense, because if someone is warning you that they are behind you, that rules out the possibility of you becoming startled to the point of punching them in the face. It rules out any backlash and conflict of any sort that may come their way from being otherwise secretive to the point of startling you and possibility causing a fight. In short, yes they're doing you a service by effectively not scaring you, but mainly they're covering their own ass. Now there's no conflict, no fight, no real need to get involved with you past simply letting you know that they're behind you. They may not even need to explain what they're doing as long as you're comfortable enough to where you won't turn around and question them because of how seemingly aware of your surroundings you are. Speaking of surroundings, hiding in plain sight is the best place to hide because when people see the same things everyday, those things become much less interesting and over time people stop talking about them and stop asking questions. They get used to seeing these same things and become comfortable with what they think they know. So... let me tie this together. Edward Snowden leaks information, people talk about that information and it becomes an opinionated war waged among We The People. An opinionated battle between each individual with what they think is going on, given the information leaked. However, the fact that this information was even "leaked" in the first place, better yet provided, was a very clever and intentional move in this secretive game of chess we call life as we know it. Because yes, it was a move made by someone in this world we live in, and yes, this world we live in is effectively a gigantic chess board. After a while people become less and less interested in the things Snowden is leaking, even if they may be true. They stop caring, they quit paying attention and they move on with their lives. Eventually they'll either begin to ignore it or they'll forget about it. Either way, they've effectively become desensitized to the notion, to the idea that whatever Snowden is saying may possibly be true. There you have it, a nation that's heard it all. A nation that has become used to the very idea that they're possibly being watched, without being told directly by anyone other than a "whistle-blower". Now it's no longer a conflict for the US, because we've been warned, we've been disclosed and we're no longer scared of the idea of being monitored along with any other tyrannical notions. Now, whatever happens effectively becomes small talk and is easily hidden and confused with all of the murmuring opinions of We The People. It's a mildly difficult concept or notion to explain but in short this is what I believe.

If you're interested in history (especially American history) but were bored to death by the sugar-coated cliff notes version you were taught in middle/high school, I'd HIGHLY recommend checking out The Dollop (if you don't already know it). It's similar to this story in that they do deep dives into commonly taught stories from history but they don't shy away from the gritty, real life details, etc. If you enjoyed learning sbout the reality of Snowden's experience/ordeal, I think The Dollop is perfect for you. Plus both guys are comedians so the show is hilarious while being informative and enlightening. A couple other shows that do sorta like "dark side of history" (which is to say: the complicated, untidy realities behind history's pretty stories and myths): - Government Secrets (w/ Lee Camp & Graham Ellwood) - Behind the Bastards - Dan Carlin's Hardcore History  And a couple authors:  - Matt Taibbi - Chris Hedges  And a couple of whistleblowers/legit American heroes similar to Snowden you may not have heard of: - John Kiriakou - Daniel Ellsburg - Steven Donziger - Smedley Butler

St. Matthew 7 Judge not, that you may not be judged,  2 For with what judgment you judge, you shall be judged: and with what measure you mete, it shall be measured to you again.  3 And why seest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye; and seest not the beam that is in thy own eye?  4 Or how sayest thou to thy brother: Let me cast the mote out of thy eye; and behold a beam is in thy own eye?  5 Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye.  6 Give not that which is holy to dogs; neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest perhaps they trample them under their feet, and turning upon you, they tear you.  7 Ask, and it shall be given you: seek, and you shall find: knock, and it shall be opened to you.  8 For every one that asketh, receiveth: and he that seeketh, findeth: and to him that knocketh, it shall be opened.  9 Or what man is there among you, of whom if his son shall ask bread, will he reach him a stone?  10 Or if he shall ask him a fish, will he reach him a serpent?  11 If you then being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children: how much more will your Lord God, the Father who is in heaven, give good things to them that ask him?  12 All things therefore whatsoever you would that men should do to you, do you also to them. For this is the law and the prophets.  13 Enter ye in at the narrow gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way that leadeth to destruction, and many there are who go in thereat.  14 How narrow is the gate, and strait is the way that leadeth to life: and few there are that find it!  15 Beware of false prophets, who come to you in the clothing of sheep, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.  16 By their fruits you shall know them. Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?  17 Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit, and the evil tree bringeth forth evil fruit.  18 A good tree cannot bring forth evil fruit, neither can an evil tree bring forth good fruit.  19 Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit, shall be cut down, and shall be cast into the fire.  20 Wherefore by their fruits you shall know them.  21 Not every one that saith to me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven: but he that doth the will of my Lord God, the Father who is in heaven, he shall enter into the kingdom of heaven.  22 Many will say to me in that day: Lord, Lord, have not we prophesied in thy name, and cast out devils in thy name, and done many miracles in thy name?  23 And then will I profess unto them, I never knew you: depart from me, you that work iniquity.  24 Every one therefore that heareth these my words, and doth them, shall be likened to a wise man that built his house upon a rock,  25 And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and they beat upon that house, and it fell not, for it was founded on a rock.  26 And every one that heareth these my words, and doth them not, shall be like a foolish man that built his house upon the sand,  27 And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and they beat upon that house, and it fell, and great was the fall thereof.  28 And it came to pass when Lord God, the Great King Jesus Christ had fully ended these words, the people were in admiration at his doctrine.  29 For he was teaching them as one having power, and not as the scribes and Pharisees.    Word of the Blessed Lord God, the King.  Thank You Blessed Lord God, the King and Savior Jesus Christ.    All you great numerous enemies; the enemy of the holy death of my Lord God, the King and Master Jesus Christ on the Cross of Calvary; the prince of darkness and iniquity, the father of all liars; I stand on the death of my Lord and Master Jesus Christ and offer His pains, wounds, and the Precious Blood of His left hand to the Eternal Father Lord God for your downfall, your destruction and your scourging. Amen. Precious Blood of my Lord and Master Jesus Christ - reign in me and in the lives of all men. Amen.    O holy loving Father, Lord God, the King of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, Who protected the Israelites of old in His holy wings in the dryness of the cold and hot desert; I offer You the holy death of my Master and Savior, Jesus Christ, for the protection of Your people who are scattered all over the world. May the Blood and water wash and strengthen, save and cleanse us that we might find home in the Sacred Side of Your Holy Son that opens for all men. Amen. Sacred Side of Lord God, the King Jesus Christ - be our home for safety. Amen.    Omnipotent and Omniscient Lord God, the King, Lord God, the King of Elijah and the prophets, look at the Sacred Head of Your only-begotten Holy Son and have mercy. Arise and save Your people. I offer You all the shame, the pains, the wounds and the Precious Blood from the Sacred Head of Your Holy Son for all Your children who are living in these perilous times. Strengthen our true faith through the mockery of Your Holy Son, Lord Jesus Christ, and save us through the Precious Blood from His Sacred Head. May we, through the sufferings of Your Holy Son, Jesus Christ, learn to suffer in You and die in You. Amen. Holy tortures of Lord God, the King Jesus Christ - increase our true faith. Amen.    Merciful and holy loving Father Lord God, the King, Your wish is that all men shall be saved. Kindly look on Your rejected and condemned Holy Son Who suffered many tortures and will suffer many through the sins of Your people. Look and see what sin has done to your only-begotten Holy Son. I offer for all Your people who are living in these ungodly and wicked days, all the tortures, pains, rejection and shame of your Son, Lord Jesus Christ, to You, for the true faith to withstand trials and holy patience to withstand long torture. May they through the suffering of Your only Holy Son, fight to the end. Amen. Our Lord God, Jesus Christ the King's torture - increase our true faith. Precious Blood of Lord God, the King Jesus Christ - save us. Amen.

St. Matthew 6 Take heed that you do not your justice before men, to be seen by them: otherwise you shall not have a reward of your Father Lord God, the Great King who is in heaven.  2 Therefore when thou dost an almsdeed, sound not a trumpet before thee, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the streets, that they may be honoured by men. Amen I say to you, they have received their reward.  3 But when thou dost alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doth.  4 That thy alms may be in secret, and thy Father Lord God, the Great King who seeth in secret will repay thee.  5 And when ye pray, you shall not be as the hypocrites, that love to stand and pray in the synagogues and corners of the streets, that they may be seen by men: Amen I say to you, they have received their reward.  6 But thou when thou shalt pray, enter into thy chamber, and having shut the door, pray to thy Father Lord God, the Great King in secret: and thy Father Lord God, the Great King who seeth in secret will repay thee.  7 And when you are praying, speak not much, as the heathens. For they think that in their much speaking they may be heard.  8 Be not you therefore like to them, for your Father Lord God, the Great King knoweth what is needful for you, before you ask him.  9 Thus therefore shall you pray: Our Father who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name.  10 Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven.  11 Give us this day our supersubstantial bread.  12 And forgive us our debts, as we also forgive our debtors.  13 And lead us not into temptation. But deliver us from evil. Amen.  14 For if you will forgive men their offences, your heavenly Father will forgive you also your offences.  15 But if you will not forgive men, neither will your Father Lord God, the Great King forgive you your offences.  16 And when you fast, be not as the hypocrites, sad. For they disfigure their faces, that they may appear unto men to fast. Amen I say to you, they have received their reward.  17 But thou, when thou fastest anoint thy head, and wash thy face;  18 That thou appear not to men to fast, but to thy Father who is in secret: and thy Father Lord God, the Great King who seeth in secret, will repay thee.  19 Lay not up to yourselves treasures on earth: where the rust, and moth consume, and where thieves break through and steal.  20 But lay up to yourselves treasures in heaven: where neither the rust nor moth doth consume, and where thieves do not break through, nor steal.  21 For where thy treasure is, there is thy heart also.  22 The light of thy body is thy eye. If thy eye be single, thy whole body shall be lightsome.  23 But if thy eye be evil thy whole body shall be darksome. If then the light that is in thee, be darkness: the darkness itself how great shall it be!  24 No man can serve two masters. For either he will hate the one, and love the other: or he will sustain the one, and despise the other. You cannot serve Lord God, the Great King and mammon.  25 Therefore I say to you, be not solicitous for your life, what you shall eat, nor for your body, what you shall put on. Is not the life more than the meat: and the body more than the raiment?  26 Behold the birds of the air, for they neither sow, nor do they reap, nor gather into barns: and your heavenly Father Lord God, the Great King feedeth them. Are not you of much more value than they?  27 And which of you by taking thought, can add to his stature by one cubit?  28 And for raiment why are you solicitous? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow: they labour not, neither do they spin.  29 But I say to you, that not even Solomon in all his glory was arrayed as one of these.  30 And if the grass of the field, which is to day, and to morrow is cast into the oven, Lord God, the Great King doth so clothe: how much more you, O ye of little faith?  31 Be not solicitous therefore, saying, What shall we eat: or what shall we drink, or wherewith shall we be clothed?  32 For after all these things do the heathens seek. For your Father Lord God, the Great King knoweth that you have need of all these things.  33 Seek ye therefore first the kingdom of Lord God, the Great King, and his justice, and all these things shall be added unto you.  34 Be not therefore solicitous for to morrow; for the morrow will be solicitous for itself. It is too caught up in trivialities and emotionalism over past wrongs to focus on future progress. Nothing improves under these ideas and policies - it's about power games for those involved more than real justice.
Â @scratchpennyÂ  colonization and slavery was necessary ?

Â @mjjonez4545Â  Yes. In our reality, we wouldn't be where we are today if it weren't for those earlier actions/practices/circumstances. Was it good? No. But like I said, this is the way of the world and nature. Human evolution and improvement happen with struggle and suffering. Slavery and conquest were practiced by virtually every civilization throughout human history. And historically, land has always been won and controlled by force. The Europeans just took those concepts further with superior technology (at the time). But the very brutality of those practices is what has allowed us to overcome them today. For those things to be deemed evil and wrong, society had to evolve into the right system and circumstances to see them as such. That's our current system (liberal democracy) that achieved that. It's something to be proud of IMO. There was no guarantee that slavery would be almost universally outlawed today if it weren't for our system. And our system is the most prominent force against those still practicing forms of slavery. We've made tremendous progress and have learned from many of our earlier mistakes!

One thing about the army he mentioned is incorrect because I was in the exact same situation as he was. He went AMA which is against medical advice and in those situation the Army is no longer responsible for your injury they tell you this upfront and try to talk you out of it. If you take the discharge he is talking about, you have to heal at the base and once you are cleared you are discharged and sent home and have a line of credit they call it for that injury where the army pays for forever for any issues regarding that injury. I have a line of credit but i chose to stay in and heal and return to training. I was offered the discharge and they do everything in their power to prevent you from going ama. Those are two different things. I could have healed and took the discharge and been covered.   Did AMA and took the discharge and not been covered. I was at basic training location for an extra 5 months for my injury so if he was released after one month he did the AMA route. I too had bilateral fractures. They want you on cruches for a month min and some in wheel chairs. Then You have to go to rehab for x amount of weeks. So he was either lied to or is not telling the whole story.

When their veil of secrecy is shredded and they can no longer rely on a phony cover story to misinform the public, they resort to admittingâ€”sometimes even volunteeringâ€”some of the truth while still managing to withhold the key and damaging facts in the case. There was one point in the discussion where it was brought up that people were not aware that these things happened or were happening, prior to someone telling them that they were or could be happening.   Such a statement could be true, in most cases, involving what people do and do not know or are aware of, but would not always be true. There are those of us--I know that I would not be the only one--where we were aware of something and knew intuitively that it existed in some form, perhaps not the exact form--but only needed an assurance or an appropriate qualification that such things did, indeed, exist; we needed validation.  When I say validation, I am not talking about the twisted form of the word, involving validation of one's own existence, I am speaking of specific validation involving exclusive ideas or methods.   The point is, that many things are already known to some of us, but we cannot prove them and, as Ed pointed out, the question then becomes: "How do we share what we know with a multitude of others, and how do we provide evidence of its existence?"  Intuition concerning the awareness of the existence of ideas and methods is a mother fucker if one cannot prove the existence of the ideas or methods which one is aware of intuitively.  When Ed initially released his information to the press and the press exposed it to the public, there were those of us whom already were aware of it.  We were aware of it even before Wyden broached it.  We became more familiar with it when studying the Patriot Act.  I became familiar with it when I did a report on the Patriot Act in 2004.   The initial awareness of such things as surveillance possibilities actually stemmed from fundamental religious teachings forced on children by their zealot parents.  "God knows everything.  God sees everything.  God knows what you know before you know it.  God has a plan for everyone and everything in existence."  Well...if God had knowledge of these things, then it must be true that Santa Claus really does know if children are good or bad, and his list must be extensive.  Even after a child discovers that Santa is not real, the idea that some 'God' knows what is happening everywhere, at all times, remains in his mind.  At least until the child decides that this 'God' cannot be real either, because if he knows what is happening everywhere, at all times, and he is not doing anything about it, then he must not be the 'God' that his parents claim he is.  That would leave the all-knowing, all-seeing ability to some other greater power, because only a greater power than humans, with their limited senses, could possibly achieve it.   What could that greater power be?  Extra-terrestrial life?  Who fucking knows?  But now, it does not come as a surprise when humans finally achieve these things.  Humans are no longer limited in their 'surveillance' by the position of satellites or how many satellites are in orbit.  Humans are no longer restricted, in observing events and people on earth, by aircraft availability and positioning, or budgets and manpower to do 'intelligence gathering'.  We always assumed, during the Cold War, that the United States knew exactly where all threats to U.S. citizens were and that surveillance would keep us safe from nuclear missile threats.  If only we had known how wrong we were.  Sometimes, being oblivious is a blessing.

I like Joe's show, mostly because he talks to any and every one, no matter what side of the aisle they're on.  Letting the interviewee talk and never challenging anything he says, especially if controversial or something that doesn't make sense, is not what normally happens on his show.  I understand why he probably didn't.  I agree listening is important, but Snowden is very polarizing, he's not a scientist, or a doctor, or a history professor with years of schooling AND experience.  He's someone who was given too much access to information he had no business seeing.  It irks me that so many see him as a hero, do you really think the Russian Government is giving him asylum out of the goodness of their hearts?

That's why Joe is great at these interviews, he can pick up on the energy of the person he's talking to. He has a light-hearted mma guy and they go back and forth, he jokes with the comedians but keeps the dialogue going. But here with Snowden, which I think Joe knew the gravity of this guest, you just let him talk and listen. Snowden had serious topics that were important to be heard, and he just stayed quiet and let him go for those. And he still was very human with him and made him feel comfortable to talk about whatever he wanted to. Joe is the GOAT in my opinion on interviews

I worked at the Dept of Defense from 2002 until 2019. I was a field operations specialist. I worked around fleet and facilities. I was basically briefed on standard issued military vehicles as well as top secret vehicles. Most of those were contracted out to Orbital ATK, Aerojet and Northrop Grumman. There's a huge difference between what the public believes and the capabilities we actually possess. During my tenure I signed 41 NDAs. Many of those have expired. However there are several that don't expire until 2040.  I can't imagine living like this gentleman. I understand his position. There are a few things I would like the world to know about. I resigned due to stress. I'm living an easier simple life today and a proud father of 2 little boys. I can't fathom the time away from my little guys I would have had to sacrifice.

And Snowden's claim, that "no one was hurt" as a result of his actions, is verifiably false.  It is a proven fact that the perpetrators of the 2015 terrorist attack in France had been able to avoid detection precisely because of information Snowden revealed.

The espionage act maybe similar to the â€œenemy of the stateâ€ in some countries? This different court procedure is only possible if the country is at war or civil war and the person is accused of doing something for the enemy against the own state. A political anthropology teacher once told me they researched what have countries around the world in common when they slowly move from democracy to dictatorship. So all kind of countries Asian African Latin American: what were the steps to go from democracy to dictatorship. It turned out no matter how different the context of each country was, they all had similar steps. The researchers made a top 5 of processes that make democracy slide into another system. Using that â€œenemy of the stateâ€ procedure for their people, without war: is on top of that list. (No longer one law for everyone but two: a political court and the normal crime court: you see the military war court slowly getting a bigger role in society). Other steps are less freedom of press and freedom of speech, and sliding into a mentality of: if your not with us you are against us. Sometimes the threat of a coup is used to declare a state of emergency like Erdogan of Turkey did. But the â€œenemy of stateâ€ court case without press or public is then stretched to people who could not possibly have been at the alleged coup but they â€œsimpathizedâ€ (that is the ultimate result of zero sum game thinking: you must say and show you are with us or else you are a suspect). So it also becomes a case of not only what someone really did but also what they could possibly do (preventive attack). And another step on that list is: less and less political parties to choose from. So there might be two but they are the same.

Regarding potential pardon for Snowden, here's a great article:  https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/16/edward-snowden-pardon-447263 Snowden is charismatic and really swayed me away from my initial feelings that he was a traitor...to thinking he was a noble patriot and that there are many shades of "traitor".  But, after reading the above article, I've started to think that this is a problem of his own making and he mishandled his "civil disobedience"...badly.  His situation is a result of his bad decision-making and poor choices; however, intelligent, articulate and personable he may be.  No matter how you package treason, it is still treason.  And, if pardoned, it opens the door for any federal employee to take similar actions, even if they are misguided in their thinking, and put the nation's security at risk just because they think something is wrong, no matter whether it is or not.  There are whistleblower channels and protection for federal workers that he could have used.  Do we really believe the Russians gave him permanent residency without something in return?  Even after all of the philosophizing and spin Snowden artfully uses to defend his actions, they still remain treasonous.

There's a dog that isn't barking here. The data points that he is giving us are perfectly valid and he makes a lot of good points, but the shape he is giving us to connect between those dots is a total misdirection. Listening to him talk about this problem ("joe, what's the worst thing you ever typed in your search bar?"), The natural response is to think, "oh my God, they could show the stepsister porn to my parents!" But the things that people worry about on a personal scale are not the things we need to be concerned about. The threat of mass surveillance is a collective one. When our government authorizes the collection of this strategic data, they are agreeing to the eventuality that our enemies will get that data. If you have a Facebook page, the Chinese government has that data. Iran has it. North korea has it. Russia has it. If north korea wants to find its covert activities with stolen credit card numbers, those numbers are much easier to get with mass surveillance on every network. If china wants to steal the software for the ps5 so they can sell a $50 knockoff, they can do that because all of those people's email accounts are being copied and pasted into a dozen different databases. If russia wants to cripple the imminent presidency of Hillary clinton and maybe even install a stooge who is dying for a deal in moscow, then they can have more success than they ever dreamed, because the american electorate is being spied on in microscopic detail by people who lack the competence to do so discreetly. They are betraying us to every kind of enemy every single day, and that is treasonous. It's not about your porn.

I remember in 2013 when the humble hero Snowden released his information.  Figured that was clearly the beginning of the end for the rampant government spying and surveillance. Yet here we are a full 7+ years later, and surveillance in society is just as common as in 2013, if not more so:  smartphones are ubiquitous, traffic cameras and house security cameras are increasingly common, Google, Amazon, and Facebook still collect and store massive amounts of data regarding their users' behavior.  So many (rightly) may wonder why the surveillance state still exists today, in spite of Snowden blowing the door wide open exposing such invasive practices. Snowden explains why in his final sentence of the interview at 2:48:12.  "You can't awaken someone who's pretending to be asleep." Why does such power and control exist today even well after it has been exposed and everyone knows about it?  Part of the reason is because that power is perpetuated not by the "big brother" or shadowy powerful elites, but ironically by *ourselves*.  How, you may ask?  Two words:  self policing. For those who are willing to bear with me for a brief moment of academia, an old guy named Michel Foucault alluded to precisely this kind of control, through a concept of a prison called "the panopticon" and "disciplinary power".  I'm sure you, dear reader, can check Wikipedia, but taken verbatim (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michel_Foucault):  "Since the prisoners will never be able to know whether they are being watched or not at a given moment, they will internalize the disciplinary power and regulate their own behavior (as if they were constantly being watched)."  The key takeaway is that the people themselves regulate their own behavior.  Anyone ever feel the silent judgement of their co-workers if they decide to leave the office right at 5:00 pm?  Yep, that's a version of the self-regulating behavior that Foucault was talking about.  No one is forcing you to stay at your office desk past 5:00 pm, but the unspoken message is "If you leave early (or even when you're "allowed" to), the boss won't give you that next big promotion."  And so office-workers frequently stay at work longer than they would like, because of the social regulation through the policing of their co-workers.  "I can't leave work early or Sally will tell my boss and I'll get in trouble."  Or think of Dwight Schrute from "The Office" episode when he documented the names of each of his coworkers when they left the office a few minutes early on a Friday.   Thus this self regulation also has the added benefit for those in power in that it creates an environment of distrust of your colleagues and coworkers; you never know if your behavior will be observed and reported to the authorities.  How much non-conforming behavior do you think you could get away with around your co-workers if you never knew when one of them would "tattle" on you to your boss.  And so in such a way, your behavior in the 21st century America is highly regulated, socialized, and normalized.  And you probably aren't even aware just how extensively it is.  So this is what Snowden is referring to in his last sentence:  you can't help people become free when they acknowledge that they're imprisoned and controlled, but are only pretending not to recognize that they are.  If you'd like to learn more about Foucault's Panopticon concept and how it totally applies to our present-day mode of living, there's a great video explaining it called "What is Foucault's Panopticon? An Introduction to a Revolutionary Theory":  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uFbywfzu-jI "It is a regime enforced not from the outside such as Nazism or totalitarianism states, but actually perpetuated *from within*."

There are numerous political problems where the solution appears simple until you drill down into it.  In the case of Edward Snowden, while the actions he took were most likely with noble intentions, they were still illegal under the US legal definition of treason.  Whoever, owing allegiance to the United States, levies war against them or adheres to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort within the United States or elsewhere, is guilty of treason and shall suffer death, or shall be imprisoned not less than five years and fined under this title but not less than $10,000; and shall be incapable of holding any office under the United States.  In leaking classified information into the public domain, Snowden effectively provided aid to US enemies - even if his intention was just to call out some rather questionable practices of the US intelligence community.  So for any US president to pardon Snowden, they would have to pardon someone legally branded a traitor. Not exactly a trivial crime. Compounding that now is the fact that Snowden has been based in Moscow for a few years - leaving it relatively undetermined how much information he has shared with Russian authorities in the mean time.  Despite Snowdenâ€™s claims that he intended to flee to South America and that the US cancelling his passport once in Russia[1] left him stuck there, the fact remains that he has been a guest of the Russian government for a troubling period of time.  So now, any sitting president looking at pardoning Snowden must take into account the crime of treason (if it wasnâ€™t a crime, thereâ€™d be nothing to pardon) as well as his situation in exile, i.e. being awfully chummy with the Russians - even if only out of necessity.  Democrat or Republican, a decision by a sitting US president to pardon someone with that history is pretty loaded and will only become more so as time marches on. Itâ€™s just not as straightforward as initial appearances make out.

I remember when internet was in its infancy, someone I knew was doing some research. He had been bragging to his father, who told me, a kid at that time. He was working with algorithms for surveillance for communication over the border. The algorithms were listening after "interesting" words. This was back in the early 1980s. It is like Murphys law: What can happen, will happen. If it goes sour, we can lock into a very bad development. Basically your communication near something connected to internet, is not private. It were never meant to be. The problem is that more and more of our lives relates to internet. By now there probably exist a lot of personality profiles on me on internet. But if Hillary, Biden..or even Obama were subjuct to 10% of the media scrutiny that Trump is, my God what would we find. It's not that Trump is this squeaky clean, selfless hero. It's that our corrupt,& biased media only shines the light on 1 side. While they beat the bushes looking for Trump's crimes,& these far right NAZIs that are always on the verge of mayhem supposedly, we have actual ANTIFA,& BLM thugs,& terrorists rioting,looting & intimidating people-in multiple cities, almost daily, for months. While we are always told the GOP is out trying to suppress minority voters-& granted that has happened in the past-we are supposed to ignore all the funny shit that clearly went on in this election,& just believe our elections are totally straight up again..after we were supposed to believe Hillary, Stacey Abrams,& Gore were robbed. (i think Gore might have been, but point is the media was fine with him suing.)  Let me be clear, I haven't seen sufficient evidence-let alone in sufficient numbers-to over turn the election. But I also don't think the general public-or media-are entitled to all their evidence now.  Theres no doubt in my mind, some of the media just want their whole case, so they can debunk it,& craft narratives-whether its true or not. Their goal is to debunk,& discredit it-even if it were true. Now, the onus is on Trump's team to prove beyond a doubt-that this happened in sufficient numbers. I suspect that will be very tough,& I expect Biden will be sworn in Jan 20th. But Trump has every right (just like Gore) to pursue this legally,& has a lot of indications that something shady did happen. To hear the DNC media ripping him,& trying to pressure him to concede-makes me wonder what they are hiding. But none of it is close to enough evidence to over turn anything. Unlike Hillary-Trump has a lot of circumstantial evidence,& clear examples of Democratic election officials & politicians-particularly the PA AG,& Michigan governor-doing very suspicious things,& flat out acting like they have something to hide. But the burden is on Trump to prove this. I have a lot of suspicion, but suspicions..even circumstantial evidence isn't good enough..nor should it be. But if the roles were reversed,& these things had happened to Biden, & we went to bed with sizeable leads, in 5 key states-with GOP governors,& proof that some things did happen-not to mention they all stop counting the votes for 2 hrs-then we wake up,& Trump was easily winning those states (relatively speaking), the media would raise hell, definitively declare that Trump stole the election, etc. I have no doubt Jim Acosta,& Don Lemon wouldve already called for Trump to be arrested.   And thats my point, most of what is said about Trump, probably is true, or has some truth to it. But the problem is the exaggerations, assuming every rumor that makes him look bad must be true,& piling on, for ridiculous things-those things never happen to Democrats. The double standard is so blatant, I dont see how anyone trying to be fair, can even deny it by now. And the soft ball questions that Democrats get, compared to what Trump gets..we can't even get Biden to admit ANTIFA EXISTS! Where's the media ripping him for that? They don't, cuz they want to protect Democrats,& many sympathize with ANTIFA, at the very least. Yet Trump gets asked when he's gonna denounce right wing extremists-despite already having done so-multiple times. You can argue whether he is sincere, but if we had a bunch of far right NAZIs, rioting, looting,& burning cities-let alone for months on end-the media coverage would be far different.We just had an election, where tens of millions of us suspect the fix was in..at least to some degree..yet I see no rioting,& looting. If the roles were reversed, ya think BLM, ANTIFA,& all those "peaceful protesters," would be taking it peacefully?   The ridiculous part is this idea that we need to watch out for all these "far right NAZI extremists." No, we need to denounce,& fight against EXTREMISM of all stripes.Cult like behaviour-us vs them, black & white thinking-just cult like behaviour. That can be a religion, political..basically any group of people can become Authoritarian, or cult like. And yes, that happens from the far right,& Trump has some of those tendencies. But so domes the radical left. Despite their propaganda, they are every bit as hateful, intolerant, Authoritarian,& cult like-as anyone on the far right. Only difference is the far left hhas infected,& dominates academia, entertainment, pop culture,big tech,especially the media. So there are very few checks,& balances on them,& they know it. It emboldens them to do as they please, cuz they know the hypocritical, dishonest media will never expose them.

Great interview! It was really awesome to hear his perspective on all of this, and hear the story straight from his mouth. I did not agree with all of his assessments and opinions, but they were insightful and well articulated nonetheless. I do have a counter argument I would like to present regarding the evacuation of the CIA, NSA, etc. (just a friendly devil's advocate here).  First, the primary point being illustrated seemed to be that it represents the selfishness (or self-centered mentality) of the intelligence agencies. I do not necessarily disagree completely that this mindset probably exists at these agencies, but you also mentioned at the same time that every one of those employees would have stayed if they were presented the option to do so. That, to me, illustrates quite the opposite mentality and demonstrates a body of employees (at least the "regular Joes" at these agencies like Snowden probably was) that recognize their duty and would sacrifice themselves for it. So that brings us to the question of the leadership at these agencies, and what their mentality is in a decision like this. If these agencies are indeed the pinnacle of surveillance capabilities throughout human history (which they are), then it does stand to reason they would be viable targets (and arguably even equal or better targets than, for example, Camp David or the Pentagon). With that in mind, it comes down to risk assessment, exactly as you stated. At some point, the leader of an agency has to weigh if the potential to prevent the attacks of other planes already in the air (which he stated was a tiny percentage of a possibility, which I would agree with) is worth risking their intelligence apparatus to respond to the attacks and prevent future attacks. They have to make this decision in a short number of minutes, and they also know that if they make the wrong decision they will be criticized (and likely criticized either way regardless). I realize that making these decisions is part of their job, and that they should have more constitution to make a decision like this than me or you perhaps, but it is still not an easy decision. In my personal opinion, I could argue for the decision either way, but in this case I would argue that the odds of them being a target for one of the remaining planes is probably a higher percentage chance than the odds that they would have been able to actually intercept and stop the remaining attacks (even with full-spectrum, rigorous analysis). Don't get me wrong, if you want to say that this is their job, and they should stay and do their duty even if the risk of their demise is potentially more likely than the chance of an "intelligence breakthrough" to prevent an attack, I cannot completely disagree with that attitude (though I do find it to possibly be shortsighted and arguably reckless), but on the same token I cannot completely condemn them for choosing self-preservation in this particular situation based on the specific circumstances, especially knowing that the employees would have gladly stayed if asked to (not to mention the fact that self-preservation is also, in some regards, part of their duty to maintain a working intelligence apparatus). Please understand I am making this argument for the "ideal CIA/NSA" as if operating constitutionally and "correctly". I realize that if you take the most evil form of the CIA/NSA that people might have a hard time swallowing that argument, but that is a whole separate discussion. I am making the argument in the context of what they should be to our country.  Thanks to the 2 people who probably read this whole thing!  :)

The Manhattan Project WAS A CONSPIRACY to commit a terrorist war crime against a Japanese civilian population.   The median estimate is that 150,000 people worked on that project; 99.9% of whom did not know what they were were working on or that 150,000 other people were also working on the same project.  This was accomplished using compartmentalization; every aspect of the project was on a need to know basis.  A machinist machining a bolt did not know what it was to be used for. Faith is one of those words that is commonly used but not always understood. Some of that confusion comes from the many different ways the word faith is used in everyday conversation; a quick look at Dictionary.com shows seven different uses! One common way that people use the word faith is to refer to belief in something despite lacking any evidence for it. But is that what the Bible means by faith? The answer is a resounding no! So, when the Bible uses the word faith, what does it mean?  The closest that the Bible comes to offering an exact definition is Hebrews 11:1: â€œNow faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.â€ From this particular passage we see that the central feature of faithâ€”confidence or trust. In the Bible, the object of faith is God and his promises. A clear example of this is Abram's encounter with God in Genesis 15. In response to God's promise of countless descendants, Abram â€œbelieved the LORD, and he counted it to him as righteousnessâ€ (Gen 15:6). Commenting on this, the Apostle Paul writes, â€œNo unbelief made him waver concerning the promise of God, but he grew strong in his faith as he gave glory to God, fully convinced that God was able to do what he had promisedâ€ (Rom 4:20â€“21). Thus, faith means putting your trust in God and having confidence that he will fulfill his promises.                                                                                                                                                                                                               Faith is more than intellectual agreement. To use an old illustration, imagine you are at Niagara Falls watching a tightrope walker push a wheelbarrow across the rope high above the falls. After watching him go back and forth several times, he asks for a volunteer to sit in the wheelbarrow as he pushes it across the falls. At an intellectual level, you may believe that he could successfully push you across the rope over the falls, but you are not exercising biblical faith until you get in the wheelbarrow and entrust yourself to the tightrope walker.  Genuine biblical faith expresses itself in everyday life. James writes that â€œfaith by itself, apart from works, is deadâ€ (James 2:17). Faith works through love to produce tangible evidence of its existence in a person's life (Gal 5:6). Put another way, the obedience that pleases God comes from faith (Rom 1:5, 16:26), rather than a mere sense of duty or obligation. There is all the difference in the world between the husband who buys his wife flowers out of delight and one who buys them simply out of duty.  Faith is so important because it is the means by which we have a relationship with God: â€œFor by grace you have been saved through faithâ€ (Eph 2:8). Faith is how we receive the benefits of what Jesus has done for us. He lived a life of perfect obedience to God, died to pay the penalty for our sinful rebellion against God, and rose from the dead to defeat sin, death, and the devil. By putting our faith in him, we receive forgiveness for our sins and the gift of eternal life. So, faith means relying completely on who Jesus is and what he has done to be made right with God. Faith is choosing to believe First of all, the Christian faith professes an unreserved belief in the Bible, Godâ€™s Word to mankind â€“ true, tested and unchanging. Faith is also full and unreserved confidence in God, in His love for me, and in His power to help me whatever comes my way in life. â€œBut without faith it is impossible to please Him, for he who comes to God must believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of those who diligently seek Him.â€ Hebrews 11:6.  Faith is a choice. I need faith to become a Christian. I choose to believe in Jesus Christ, that He died for my sins, and that by believing in Him, my sins will be forgiven. The promise is clear. â€œFor God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have everlasting life.â€ John 3:16. It is faith in a Person that saves a believing soul, not faith in a particular philosophy or a code of rules.  Every Christian will agree that salvation is a gift, not something we attain to by our own efforts. â€œFor by grace you have been saved through faith, and that not of yourselves; it is the gift of God, not of works lest any man should boast.â€ Ephesians 2:8-9. To acknowledge my sin and repent from it is the first and vital step. But I still cannot save myself! â€œThe wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.â€ Romans 6:23. To receive this gift, I must believe in and personally accept Godâ€™s gift to me in His Son. The forgiveness of sins is a wonderful beginning, and brings great joy to every true believer in Jesus. It is no small thing to have the burden and guilt of sin removed from my conscience! What comes next? So I am saved by grace through an act of faith. I choose to believe. Then what? Do I still need faith? Yes! If I want to live a life that pleases the Savior I have believed in. Though the guilt of sin is gone, the indwelling sin in my nature will still be the cause of many temptations. The next verse in Ephesians 2 tells us what Godâ€™s thoughts are for us after our initial experience of salvation. â€œFor we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand that we should walk in them.â€ Ephesians 2:10. So God has something far greater, and even more wonderful in mind for us after we have believed Him for forgiveness.  It is also written in Romans 5:10: â€œFor if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.â€ Jesusâ€™ life was a life of action. â€œThough He was a Son, yet He learned obedience by the things which He suffered.â€ Hebrews 5:8. To be saved by His life, I need a faith that leads me to action. Paul calls it the obedience to the faith. (Romans 1:5)  Jesus is our great Forerunner, and the author and finisher of our faith. (Hebrews 12:2) All the heroes of faith in the old covenant acted on their faith. They did something. Every one of them believed â€“ and acted! By faith Noah prepared an ark, by faith Abraham obeyed, and so on.  (Hebrews 11)  Go to action! John writes simply: â€œIn Him was life, and the life was the light of men.â€ John 1:4. It is this light of Jesusâ€™ life that I need to walk in â€“ go to action! If I really want to obey Godâ€™s good laws of life found in His Word, I will soon find myself in a battle Almost all talk of battles and wars when concerning a Christian life refers to the inner battle that arises when a sinful thought tempts you. Godâ€™s Spirit and the flesh are at odds. When you have decided to only do... , a battle against the sin the light reveals.  This is the good fight of faith!  To win this battle, I need to believe in a power outside of myself, in the power of the Holy Spirit, in Jesus Who has promised that He can save me, and that to the uttermost. (Hebrews 7:25) This ongoing salvation is a work of faith. It has nothing to do with my feelings, which can go up and down like a yo-yo. But when I believe God, and set my heart to obey, even against my feelings or my human understanding, then God goes to action too! He sends grace and help in time of need, and all honor for the salvation gained belongs to Him!  Faith opens the door to a victorious life! By faith, we can truly overcome as He overcame! â€œThis is the victory that overcomes the world â€“ our faith.â€ 1 John 5:5. I believe in His power to save. I believe that when I take up my cross and deny myself as Jesus did, or as the Scriptures also put it, am â€œcrucified with Christ,â€ I will be victorious over sin and self. â€œI have been crucified with Christ, it is no longer I who live, but Christ lives in me and the life that I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself for me.â€ Galatians 2:20.  Faith is a precious possession! As we said to start with, it is not visible or tangible. However, Jesus said to doubting Thomas: â€œBlessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.â€ John 20:29. Peter writes about this blessedness also. â€œâ€¦ whom having not seen you love. Though now you do not see Him, yet believing, you rejoice with joy inexpressible and full of glory, receiving the end of your faith, the salvation of your souls.â€ 1 Peter 1:8-9. The result of a living faith is both visible and tangible! The disciples saw it and touched it in Jesus, and our calling as Christians is to come to this same joyful and glorious life â€“ by faith!                                        2 Thessalonians 1:7-9 7 And God will provide rest for you who are being persecuted and also for us when the Lord Jesus appears from heaven. He will come with his mighty angels, 8 in flaming fire, bringing judgment on those who donâ€™t know God and on those who refuse to obey the Good News of our Lord Jesus. 9 They will be punished with eternal destruction, forever separated from the Lord and from his glorious power. 2:38:04 what he is talking about (a button that would allow you to use a service without companies contacting ad servers and track what you are doing across platforms) is actually being implemented on iPhones very soon. It was meant to come with IOS 14 but has been delayed till early 2021 (I believe February) which would mean that EVERY SINGLE APPLICATION (whether it be Facebook Google, Amazon; or anyone else) would have to ask you permission to track you from the moment you install it, a permission which you will be able to deny while still being able to take advantage of that apps capabilities, just without it being allowed to track you across platforms. Its amazing to see companies actually doing a lot of these things that privacy activists like Snowden imagined would be ideal, however this change has undergone serious scrutiny by the likes of Facebook, because of course, it will severely affect their bottom line. Zuckerberg is against giving people this button from the get-go, as from his perspective people misunderstand what "tracking" means, and ultimately basically everyone is going to say no to it. My rebuttal to this is, is that if you are so afraid that THE MOMENT people are given a choice whether or not they want an activity to take place, you know for a fact that they are going to opt out, doesn't that say something about the activity itself? doesn't it tell you that what you are doing is wrong?
